questions.question_text: An organization wants to discover, monitor, and track the applications running on the WAN Edge device on the LAN. Which configuration achieves the goal?

discussion.content: Cisco should be paying us going thru these poorly worded questions.
Option A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
A
An organization wants to discover, , -> this means app visibility
monitor -> visibility is needed to know what to minitor
"and track" -> even with no AAR, vManage keeps graphs for apps so you have tracking

Selected Answer: A
AAR proposal is to route traffic based on the application and its performance but not to discover it, which is done by another component in cEdge.

Selected Answer: D
I believe it's D, because you're saving the exported data and thus tracking it.

What a hard question between A and D.

What do you think about: An organization wants to discover, monitor, "and track"

When you have dpi running on a Cisco Device, you can discover applications and flows passing through in real time:

show sdwan app-fwd dpi flows table
 that's real time, so you are not tracking it I think, in the time after, flow disapears at one moment normally.
When you are configuring a netflow collector, you are saving those informations, so tracking more that only in real time? what do you think?

#show sdwan app-fwd dpi flows table
Generating output, this might take time, please wait ...

Selected Answer: A
A

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/application-aware-routing.html

Enable Application Visibility on Cisco SD-WAN Devices
You can enable application visibility directly on Cisco SD-WAN devices, without configuring application-aware routing policy so that you can monitor all the applications running in all VPNs in the LAN. To do this, configure application visiblity on the router:

vEdge(config)# policy app-visibility

I would say "A". Enable Application Visibility on Cisco SD-WAN Devices
You can enable application visibility directly on Cisco SD-WAN devices, without configuring application-aware routing policy so that you can monitor all the applications running in all VPNs in the LAN. To do this, configure application visibility on the router:

vEdge(config)# policy app-visibility

A is a better choice than D, based on the wording in the docs.

Enable application visibility so that a vEdge router can monitor and track the applications running on the LAN (on vEdge routers only)."

questions.question_text: What is the default value (in milliseconds) set for the poll interval in the BFD basic configuration?

choices.D: source zone, destination zone, and zone pair
choices.C: destination zone, interface zone, and zone pair
choices.B: source zone, interface zone, and zone pair
choices.A: destination zone, interface zone, source zone, and zone pair

questions.question_text: What are the components of zone configuration in an application-aware firewall?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Zone configuration consists of the following components:

Source zone—A grouping of VPNs where the data traffic flows originate. 
Destination zone—A grouping of VPNs where the data traffic flows terminate. 
Zone pair—A container that associates a source zone with a destination zone and that applies a firewall policy to the traffic that flows between the two zones.
Firewall policy—A security policy, similar to a localized security policy, that defines the conditions that the data traffic flow from the source zone must match to allow the flow to continue to the destination zone. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/security/vedge-20-x/security-book/ent-firewall-app-aware.html#:~:text=Zone%20configuration%20consists%20of%20the,the%20data%20traffic%20flows%20terminate.

In B, the tunnel-interface configurations are under VPN1 but any transport configs should be under VPN0. The question says we want to create a peering between the CSRv and the non-SDWAN devices on the Service VPN side (look at the diagram). Has to be C.

The network team must configure EIGRP peering at HQ with devices in the SERVICE VPN connected to WAN Edge CSRv. A and C peering in VPN 0, the only that peering with service VPN is the B (VPN1)

B is wrong because public IP will not be configured under VPN1 
C is correct - Transport configured and EIGRP configured and redistributing OMP into service-side

questions.question_text: Which data policy configuration influences BGP routing traffic flow from LAN to WAN?

discussion.content:
The question requests the configuration from a Service VPN (Not VPN 0 or 512)
The direction is Egress (VPN LAN to WAN) - Exiting direction or OUT

Options A and C has "route-policy BG-AS-PREPEND in" configured which is ingress and therefore incorrect.

Option B & D are practically identical, however the action-accept operation needs to be set as accept not deny within sequence 10 for the configuration to take effect.

Option [D] is the correct option

Selected Answer: A
I´ll go witch A, even A and C look the same to me.

comments.content: they look the same for me too. I think A is a better answer. inbound policy influences outbound traffic.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
C and A look identical to me...

First look, i thought also D. Then i read one more time and... i am thinking...

Which data policy configuration influences BGP "routing traffic" flow from LAN to WAN. It means not the customer traffic itself i think (because in that case is in out direction).
How do you affect the routing traffic LAN to WAN? matching in IN this traffic, so could be A.

Selected Answer: D
A and C appear identical, and say inbound, which is wrong.
B says action deny, which is wrong
The influence is from LAN to WAN not WAN to LAN. Therefore the policy is to be applied in the OUT direction. The answer is D
